  physical_appearance: This is a pair of candlesticks. The base of the candlestick is a circular base. The body of the candlestick has several ridged circular bands
 with a wide dish in the middle. There is a metal spike on top of the candlestick to hold the candle.

  subject_terms_1: ceremonial objects Peranakan religious ceremonies altar components

  subject_terms_2: Rites and ceremonies Brass candlesticks Peranakan (Asian people) Altars Ceremonial objects

  subject_terms_3: Religious life and practices

  sgcool_label_text: This is a pair of brass candlesticks that were placed on the two tier altar. Large red or white candles would be inserted onto the sharp metal spike on the top of the candlestick. In some Peranakan homes
 beadwork or embroidery pieces would decorate the circular portion of the candlesticks.\r\n\r\nThis item is donated by the family of prominent Peranakan
 Ong Sam Leong (b. 1857
 Singapore – d. 7 February 1918
 Singapore). It comes from his ancestral home of Bukit Rose
 formerly at 259 Bukit Timah Road. Ong was a well-known successful businessman who made is money in the mining of phosphate on Christmas island
 which was historically a territory of colonial Singapore.

metadata.title_text: Brass altar candlesticks Pair of candlesticks
metadata.physical_appearance: This is a pair of candlesticks. The base of the candlestick is a circular base. The body of the candlestick has several ridged circular bands, with a wide dish in the middle. There is a metal spike on top of the candlestick to hold the candle.
metadata.subject_terms_1: ceremonial objects Peranakan religious ceremonies altar components
metadata.subject_terms_2: Rites and ceremonies Brass candlesticks Peranakan (Asian people) Altars Ceremonial objects
metadata.sgcool_label_text:
This is a pair of brass candlesticks that were placed on the two tier altar. Large red or white candles would be inserted onto the sharp metal spike on the top of the candlestick. In some Peranakan homes, beadwork or embroidery pieces would decorate the circular portion of the candlesticks.

This item is donated by the family of prominent Peranakan, Ong Sam Leong (b. 1857, Singapore – d. 7 February 1918, Singapore). It comes from his ancestral home of Bukit Rose, formerly at 259 Bukit Timah Road. Ong was a well-known successful businessman who made is money in the mining of phosphate on Christmas island, which was historically a territory of colonial Singapore.
